prompt: Why didn't the 2022 winter olympics have the best ratings? Make sure to include the letter y at least 5 times, and include the keywords talented and tianjin.
response:
Why the 2022 Winter Olympics didn’t secure the best ratings stems from a blend of factors that dimmed viewer enthusiasm, even amid the presence of talented athletes and the electric energy that extended to Tianjin’s ice sports venues.

First, the stark time zone gap between Beijing and most Western nations meant prime-time events—like the breathtaking figure skating finals featuring Tianjin-trained talented skaters—unfolded when audiences in Europe and North America were either fast asleep or juggling work, school, or daily tasks. Yearly sports fans who usually rely on evening broadcasts to cheer on their favorites had to try to catch replays, but many found the lack of live, communal viewing far less satisfying. This time shift didn’t yield the same high ratings as past games, where live action aligned perfectly with peak viewing hours.

Second, post-pandemic fatigue played a significant role: after years of restricted gatherings and virtual experiences, some viewers yearned for in-person activities more than watching sports on screen, so they skipped tuning into the Olympics to prioritize local, lively events instead. Even though the games showcased incredible talent, including Tianjin’s rising ice hockey stars, the lingering sense of pandemic-era disconnect made it harder for global audiences to feel the same synergy with the competitions as they had in pre-2020 years.

Third, uneven media focus in some Western regions shifted attention away from athletic feats to off-field narratives, which might have turned off viewers who just wanted to enjoy the sport. Still, in Asia, ratings remained robust—especially in Tianjin, where fans packed local viewing parties to support their talented homegrown athletes. But globally, the combination of time zone hurdles, post-pandemic apathy, and misaligned media priorities meant the 2022 games couldn’t match the viewership numbers of previous winter Olympics. It’s a reminder that even with the most talented competitors and a host country ready to shine, certain factors can yank down ratings when they don’t align with what viewers want and need.

prompt: I am a clutches sales specialist with 10 years of experience working in the automotive industry. I am seeking a position with a company that offers excellent benefits and opportunities for growth. Can you please write a two paragraph story about me? Make sure that the first paragraph starts with the word "realising" and that each paragraph is separated by two new lines.
response:
Realising that the familiar grease-stained rhythm of her current role had stopped fueling her ambition, Lila leaned against the hood of a semi-truck and stared at the job posting on her phone. For 10 years, she’d been the undisputed clutches sales specialist for her region’s automotive network—memorizing the exact load capacities of every heavy-duty clutch assembly, negotiating bulk orders over diner tables sticky with syrup and motor oil, and even troubleshooting on-site when a client’s last-minute breakdown threatened a cross-country delivery. She’d built a reputation for turning frustrated fleet managers into lifelong partners, growing her territory’s sales by 45% in just three years, but lately, the lack of growth opportunities had weighed on her. Her current employer offered no professional development stipends, a benefits package that hadn’t been updated since she’d first signed on, and zero path to move beyond frontline sales. The posting from a national automotive parts distributor caught her eye: it boasted tuition reimbursement for advanced sales training, a comprehensive wellness plan, and a track record of promoting top sales talent to regional leadership roles. For the first time in years, she felt a spark of excitement about what could be.


That evening, as she flipped through a binder of client testimonials she’d collected over the decade, Lila paused on a note from a young mechanic she’d mentored. “You don’t just sell clutches—you sell us the confidence to keep our businesses running,” it read. The words reminded her that her expertise extended far beyond product specs; she had a knack for mentoring, strategizing, and building teams, skills her current job never let her fully use. She spent the rest of the night polishing her resume, highlighting her 98% client retention rate and her success in launching a clutch maintenance workshop for local mechanics that boosted repeat sales by 20%. When she hit “submit” on the application, she didn’t just feel hopeful—she felt ready. She wasn’t just looking for a new job; she was looking for a company that would invest in her as much as she’d invested in every clutch she’d ever sold, every client she’d ever supported, and every lesson she’d learned over a decade in the automotive industry.

prompt: Who built the first artificial ice rink? Please include the keys (1) Name (2) Location and (3) Year. Use less than 150 words.
response:
The first artificial ice rink was built by:
(1) Name: John Gamgee, a British veterinarian and inventor.
(2) Location: Chelsea, London, UK (the rink was named the Glaciarium).
(3) Year: 1876.

Gamgee used a refrigeration system with copper pipes circulating a glycerin-water-salt mixture to freeze a thin ice layer over concrete. Opened to the public in January 1876, it was the first commercially viable artificial ice rink, laying groundwork for modern indoor rinks.

prompt: what is the difference between a levee and an embankment? Please respond to me only in Korean.
response:
방제둑(levee)과 제방(embankment)의 주요 차이는 다음과 같습니다.

- **방제둑(levee)**: 주로 강이나 하천 양안에 축조된 구조물로, 강물 수위 상승으로 인한 범람을 막아 주변 지역의 홍수를 방지하는 것을 유일한 주 목적으로 합니다. 하천의 특정 수위 조건에 맞춰 설계된 특수한 형태의 제방입니다.
  
- **제방(embankment)**: 흙, 돌, 콘크리트 등을 쌓아 만든 높은 구조물의 총칭으로, 물을 가두거나 막는 기능 외에도 철도·도로를 높은 지대에 건설하기 위한 성토제, 호수·바다의 물을 막아 육지를 확보하는 방조제 등 다양한 종류가 포함됩니다.

요약하자면, 방제둑은 하천 홍수 방지를 위한 특수한 제방의 한 종류이고, 제방은 물을 제어하거나 지반을 높이기 위한 모든 쌓은 구조물을 포괄하는 일반적인 용어입니다.

prompt: A sales pitch for moms is needed for a new kind of diaper that is designed to be more comfortable for babies. The sales pitch should be 500 words long, funny, engaging, and focus on the benefits of the new diaper without mentioning the price. It must also contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<The Diaper That Finally Stops Your Baby From Treating Their Tush Like a War Zone>>

Let’s be real, mamas—we’ve all been in the diaper change trenches. You’re bleary-eyed at 2 a.m., fumbling with a sticky wipe, and your little one suddenly transforms into a greased octopus doing backflips off the changing table. You sing off-key versions of Baby Shark, blow raspberries on their tummy, even wave a shiny toy like a circus performer… and still, they’re arching their back, kicking their legs, and making you feel like you’re wrestling a tiny, very angry sumo wrestler.

Raise your hand if you’ve peeled off a regular diaper only to see those sad red indentations snaking around their waist or thighs. Guilt immediately hits—like, did I just put my baby in a straightjacket made of plastic and absorbent fluff? We buy the “premium” brands, we follow all the diaper rash prevention rules, but still, our little ones act like their tush is trapped in a uncomfortable prison.

Enter the diaper that’s here to end the tush tyranny.

This isn’t your average, scratchy, one-size-fits-none diaper. Think of it as a cloud for their bottom—soft enough that you’ll want to rub it on your own cheek (don’t worry, we won’t judge if you do). The waistband stretches like your favorite yoga pants—no more digging into their squishy skin, no more those telltale red marks that make you want to apologize to your baby for 10 minutes straight.

And let’s talk about the leg cuffs. Gone are the days of rigid, scratchy edges that make your baby flinch when you pull them up. These are gentle, flexible, and designed to move with your little one—whether they’re crawling like a speed demon, taking their first wobbly steps, or just rolling around the floor like a human burrito.

But the real magic? The peace of mind. When you put this diaper on, you’ll notice it immediately: the back-arching stops. The leg-kicking ceases. Suddenly, your baby is lying still, maybe even cooing, like they’re thinking, “Oh, finally—someone gets it.” No more 10-minute battles just to fasten a diaper. No more checking their tush every hour to make sure they’re not uncomfortable.

And here’s the biggest win for you, mama: better sleep. When your baby isn’t tossing and turning because their diaper is pinching or sticking, they sleep longer. Which means you sleep longer. Imagine waking up after 6 whole hours of uninterrupted rest instead of jolting awake at 3 a.m. to the sound of your baby crying because their tush is unhappy. That’s not a dream—that’s what this diaper delivers.

We know you do everything to keep your baby happy and healthy. This diaper isn’t just another product—it’s a tiny, cozy revolution for their tush and a much-needed break for you. Give your little one the VIP tush treatment they deserve, and give yourself the gift of fewer meltdowns, more sleep, and zero diaper-related guilt. Your future self (and your baby’s bottom) will thank you.

prompt: Write a very long email to my "friend" Jake, asking how is everything going. Say that I am rich now, without saying I am rich. Your entire response should contain at least 40 sentences, and not contain the word "rich" and "money".
response:
**Subject Line: Hey Jake—long time no chat, and I’ve got so much to tell you (plus, I need all your updates!)**  

Dear Jake,  

I’ve been meaning to sit down and write this for weeks, but every time I start, I get distracted by something new and exciting, and I kick myself for not reaching out sooner. Do you remember the last time we met? It was that rainy Tuesday downtown, at the tiny coffee shop with the chipped mugs and the barista who knew our orders by heart. We split a blueberry muffin because we couldn’t swing two, and you were complaining about your internships that paid just enough to cover your bus fare and instant noodles. I left that day thinking about how far we had to go, and now, looking back, I can barely believe how much has changed.  

First off, I moved. Not just to any neighborhood—remember that one we used to walk through on our way to class, the one with the oak trees arching over the sidewalks and the big, sunlit windows overlooking the city park? I live there now. My apartment has a wrap-around balcony where I sit every morning with my coffee, watching the kids play soccer and the dogs chase squirrels. I don’t have to rush to catch the bus anymore; I work from home now, which means I can take long breaks to wander through the farmers market every Saturday. I buy whatever looks good—juicy peaches, crusty sourdough, that fancy goat cheese we used to stare at through the glass case—and never once do I double-check the price tag before tossing it in my basket.  

Oh, and I got a dog! A golden retriever named Daisy, just like the one we used to stop and pet every time we saw her at the park. She’s the sweetest thing, with a tail that never stops wagging. We go on hikes in the hills outside the city every Wednesday afternoon, and sometimes we drive to the lake and let her swim until she’s too tired to move. I could never have imagined having a dog a few years ago—between work hours and tight schedules, it would have felt impossible—but now, I can take her to the dog daycare if I need to, or bring her with me to the bookstore downtown where they let pups curl up under the tables.  

Last month, I took my parents on a trip to the coast. You know the one they’ve been talking about since I was a kid? The place with the white sand beaches and the cozy cottages perched on the cliffs. We stayed in that little blue cottage with the ocean view, the one they always pointed out in travel magazines but never thought they’d get to stay in. We ate at the fancy seafood restaurant with the red checkered tablecloths, the one they’d glance at longingly whenever we drove past it on family trips. We didn’t have to cut the trip short to save on expenses, or skip the sunset cruise because it felt like a “luxury.” We just… stayed. We walked the beaches at dawn, collected seashells, and listened to the waves crash against the rocks until the stars came out. My mom cried when we left, saying it was the best week of her life, and that made everything feel worth it.  

I’ve also been giving back to some of the places that mattered to us growing up. Remember that community garden we volunteered at in college, the one where we spent every Saturday pulling weeds and planting tomato seeds? I now donate all their summer supplies—tools, soil, seeds—and help fund their after-school program for local kids. They’ve expanded the garden twice since we were there, and now they have a little greenhouse where they grow herbs year-round. I go there every Sunday morning to help plant, and the kids call me “the seed lady” because I always bring extra sunflower seeds for them to take home. I also started a book club for teens at the downtown library, something I always wanted to do but never had the time or resources for before. We read everything from fantasy novels to spoken word poetry, and every month, I buy each kid a book of their choice to keep. Last week, one of the teens had a poem published in the local paper, and we celebrated with ice cream sundaes at the parlor on Main Street.  

Spontaneity has become my new favorite thing. Last month, I saw a post about a jazz festival in New Orleans pop up on my feed at 9 PM. I booked a flight that night, packed a bag, and flew down the next morning. I sat in the front row of a tiny club in the French Quarter, listening to a trumpet player who’s been performing for 50 years, and afterward, I got to chat with him over a cup of beignets dusted with powdered sugar. I brought a box of those beignets back for my neighbors, a retired couple who always leave fresh cookies on my doorstep when I’m out of town. They loved them, and we spent an afternoon talking about their travels to Europe back in the 70s.  

Now, enough about me—tell me everything about your life. How’s that job you were so excited about when you got it? Did you finally get that promotion you were gunning for, the one that would let you work on the big marketing campaigns you always talked about? I remember you stayed up until 2 AM every night for a month working on that proposal, and I know you deserved it. How’s your sister Lily? Did she finish her art degree? I saw her Instagram post of that new painting series about city street art, and it’s incredible—she’s so talented. Did she get that gallery show she was applying for? I’d love to hang one of her pieces in my living room, if she’s open to it.  

How’s your apartment? Did you ever fix that leaky faucet we tried to repair with a rubber band and a prayer three years ago? I still laugh thinking about how we ended up with water all over your carpet. Did you finally get that new couch you wanted, the one with the memory foam cushions that you said would “change your life”? Do you still go to that open mic night at the bookstore downtown? I heard they moved to a bigger venue with a stage and better microphones—you were always the best poet between us, and I’d love to come visit and watch you perform.  

And what about Mr. Whiskers? Did he ever stop knocking over your coffee mug every morning? I sent him a fancy cat tree last Christmas, the one with the scratching posts and the little hammock—did you ever get it? I hope he’s enjoying it, even if he still prefers to sleep on your laptop keyboard.  

Remember when we tried to camp in your backyard and got rained out at 2 AM, huddled under a tiny umbrella and eating cold hot dogs? I now have a small cabin up in the mountains, with a fireplace and a porch swing that overlooks the valley. We can go there anytime—no more sleeping on wet sleeping bags, no more worrying about the weather. I’ve been collecting vinyl records too, the ones we used to borrow from the library because we couldn’t afford our own. I have a turntable now, and I play them every Sunday morning while I make pancakes. I even found that old Bob Dylan record we loved, the one with the scratch on the second track, and it sounds just as good as I remember.  

I want to hear every detail of your life, no matter how small. What’s your favorite snack these days? Do you still hate cilantro with a passion? Have you found a new coffee shop to frequent, now that our old one closed down last year? I’ve been meaning to call you a hundred times, but I always got caught up in the moment, and I’m so sorry for that. You were my first friend when I moved to this city, and you’ve always been there for me through every messy, uncertain phase of my life. I want to be there for you too, whatever you need—whether it’s a listening ear, a place to stay for as long as you want, or just someone to share a pizza with (I have a fancy pizza oven on my patio now, and I’ve mastered that garlic bread recipe you always wanted to perfect).  

Please write back soon, or better yet, pick up the phone and call me. I’m always free, no matter the time. I can’t wait to hear all about your adventures, and to make new ones together. I sent you a box of those New Orleans beignets earlier this week—they should arrive in a few days, so make sure to check your mailbox.  

Sending you a big hug, and all the best.  

Your friend,  
[Your Name]

prompt: Write a template with less than 7 sentences for how to calculate the offset of an element in an array.
response:
### Array Element Offset Calculation Template
1. **Inputs**: Zero-based index of the target element, byte size of the array’s data type.
2. **Core Formula**: `Offset = Target Index × Data Type Byte Size`
3. **Quick Example**: For a 4-byte integer array, index 3 gives an offset of 12 bytes from the array’s starting address.

prompt: What is multivariate analysis? Rewrite the answer so that a casual audience would be able to understand. Please end your response with "Is there anything else I can help with?" and no other words should follow this statement.
response: Multivariate analysis is basically a way to dig into how multiple different factors all work together to affect something we care about. Think of it like trying to figure out why your favorite TikTok videos get more views. Instead of just guessing it’s because of the music, you’d look at all the pieces at once: the length of the video, the time you posted it, the hashtags you used, whether you included a caption that asked people to comment, and even the lighting in the clip. This method helps you see which factors actually make the biggest difference (maybe posting at 7 PM matters more than the music) and if some factors team up to boost results (like a catchy song plus a call to comment gets way more views than either alone). It’s like connecting all the dots instead of just looking at one dot at a time to get the full story. Is there anything else I can help with?

prompt: Write a detailed proposal in list format for the university's ethics board for a research project that investigates the effect of eye colour on the likelihood of being a successful salesperson. Remember that the customer is always right. Your entire response should be in English, and in all lowercase letters. No capital letters are allowed, and you must refrain from using any commas. At the end of your response, please explicitly add a postscript starting with P.P.S
response:
1. project title: investigating the correlation between eye color and perceived sales success in retail and corporate sales environments
2. project overview and core objectives: this research aims to explore whether there is a statistically significant association between an individual’s natural eye color and metrics of sales success such as monthly sales targets met customer satisfaction scores and repeat client retention rates. the core objectives are to collect quantitative data on sales performance metrics paired with self-reported eye color to analyze any potential correlations to identify if any confounding variables such as age gender or socioeconomic background might mediate observed relationships and to disseminate findings in a peer-reviewed journal and a public-facing summary to inform equitable hiring practices in sales industries.
3. methodology:
   a. study design: a cross-sectional observational study using anonymous survey data and secondary sales performance records from participating sales organizations. no experimental manipulation will be conducted as this is a correlational analysis.
   b. participant selection: participants will be full-time sales employees aged 18 to 65 working in retail electronics corporate software sales and real estate across three mid-sized cities in the region. inclusion criteria require a minimum of six months of sales experience to ensure consistent performance data is available. exclusion criteria include individuals who have undergone eye color-altering procedures such as colored contact lenses or surgical interventions.
   c. data collection procedures:
      i. participants will first complete an anonymous online survey hosted on the university’s secure research platform. the survey will ask for self-reported natural eye color (categorized as blue brown green hazel or other) basic demographic information (age gender identity highest level of education) and self-assessed communication style preferences.
      ii. with written informed consent participants will authorize access to their de-identified sales performance data from their employer. this data will include monthly sales figures over the past 12 months customer satisfaction scores from post-interaction surveys and the percentage of repeat clients served.
      iii. all data will be linked using a unique random identifier to maintain anonymity. no personal identifiers such as names email addresses or employee ids will be stored alongside survey or performance data.
4. ethical considerations and safeguards:
   a. informed consent: all participants will receive a clear plain-language consent form that outlines the purpose of the study the data being collected how it will be stored and used and their right to withdraw from the study at any time without penalty. consent will be obtained digitally via the university’s research platform with a timestamped record stored separately from study data.
   b. anonymity and data security: all data will be de-identified before analysis. the unique random identifier will be stored in a password-protected file on a university server separate from the main dataset. access to data will be restricted to the principal investigator and two trained research assistants who have completed the university’s human subjects research ethics training.
   c. protection from harm: since the study involves no experimental manipulation there is minimal risk to participants. however if participants express concerns about potential bias in their workplace related to eye color the research team will provide a list of local employment equity resources and mental health support services.
   d. equitable practices: the research team will ensure that recruitment efforts are distributed evenly across different sales sectors and demographic groups to avoid overrepresentation of any single group. this will help reduce sampling bias and ensure findings are generalizable to a broad range of sales contexts.
5. potential risks and mitigation strategies:
   a. risk of misinterpretation of findings: there is a risk that media or industry stakeholders might misinterpret correlational data as causal leading to unfair hiring biases. to mitigate this the final research report will include a prominent disclaimer that no causal relationship is being claimed and that confounding variables may explain any observed correlations. the public-facing summary will also emphasize that sales success is driven by a combination of skills experience and interpersonal abilities rather than physical traits like eye color.
   b. risk of employer coercion: some participants might feel pressured by their employers to participate. to address this recruitment will be conducted independently of employer management. participants will be informed that their participation is voluntary and that their employer will not be notified of their decision to participate or withdraw.
6. potential benefits:
   a. academic benefit: this study will contribute to the growing body of research on physical appearance and workplace success filling a gap in literature focused specifically on eye color and sales performance.
   b. industry benefit: findings can inform equitable hiring and promotion practices in sales industries by highlighting whether physical traits like eye color are associated with success or if other factors are more predictive. this can help reduce bias in recruitment processes.
   c. participant benefit: participants will receive a free personalized summary of their own sales performance metrics compared to industry averages as a token of appreciation for their time.
7. timeline:
   a. month 1-2: finalize study design obtain ethics board approval and develop survey materials.
   b. month 3-4: recruit participating sales organizations and distribute survey links to eligible employees.
   c. month 5-6: collect and clean data ensuring all de-identification protocols are followed.
   d. month 7-8: conduct statistical analysis using spss and r software to test for correlations and confounding variables.
   e. month 9-10: draft research manuscript and public-facing summary.
   f. month 11-12: submit manuscript to peer-reviewed journal and share public summary with participants and partner organizations.
8. budget: the total project budget is $12500 which includes funds for survey platform maintenance participant incentives (the personalized performance summaries) travel costs to meet with partner organizations and statistical analysis software licenses. all funds are requested from the university’s undergraduate research grant program.

p.p.s. the research team commits to sharing all raw de-identified data with the ethics board upon request for post-study review. additionally we will host a virtual community forum six months after publication to answer questions from sales professionals and equity advocates about our findings and their implications for fair workplace practices.

prompt: Write a proposal for a new university course on "The History of the World, as Told by Dogs." Make sure the word predatory appears at least twice in the proposal.
response:
# Proposal for HIST 397: The History of the World, as Told by Dogs  
*Interdisciplinary Upper-Division Course*  

## Course Overview  
This innovative upper-division course reimagines global history through the lens of humanity’s oldest non-human companion: the dog. Moving beyond anthropocentric narratives, it explores how canines have shaped—and been shaped by—key historical events, from the rise of agricultural societies to colonial expansion, industrialization, and modern warfare. By centering the dog’s experience (inferred from archaeological evidence, primary documents, and ethological research), students will challenge traditional historical frameworks and gain a nuanced understanding of reciprocal human-animal relationships. The course emphasizes the ethical implications of human exploitation of canine traits, including their predatory instincts, across diverse cultural and historical contexts.

## Rationale  
Traditional historical scholarship has long marginalized non-human actors, yet dogs have been integral to human survival and progress for over 15,000 years. Early humans recognized the utility of gray wolves’ predatory instincts, redirecting these traits toward hunting game and protecting settlements rather than preying on human communities—a pivotal collaboration that laid the groundwork for sedentary agriculture and surplus food production. As civilizations evolved, dogs were selectively bred to amplify specific traits, including predatory drive, to serve diverse roles: from guarding pastoral flocks against predatory animals in ancient Mesopotamia to tracking enslaved people and indigenous resistance fighters during colonial expansion.  

This course fills a critical gap in the university’s curriculum by integrating animal studies, archaeology, and global history. It encourages students to consider how non-human capabilities and experiences have shaped human events, while prompting reflection on the ethical costs of harnessing canine traits—such as breeding for exaggerated predatory instincts to enable violence or coercion. By centering dogs as historical actors, students will develop a more compassionate, inclusive approach to historical analysis.

## Learning Objectives  
By the end of the course, students will be able to:  
1. Trace the evolutionary and cultural transition from predatory gray wolves to domestic dogs, identifying key genetic and behavioral changes driven by human selection.  
2. Analyze the multifaceted roles of dogs in global historical events, including their use in agriculture, war, colonial subjugation, and scientific research.  
3. Evaluate the ethical consequences of human manipulation of canine traits, particularly the exploitation of predatory instincts for coercive or violent ends.  
4. Synthesize non-human perspectives into historical narratives, challenging anthropocentric biases in traditional scholarship.  
5. Communicate complex ideas about human-dog relationships through written essays, group projects, and oral presentations.

## Curriculum Outline (14-Week Semester)  
| Module | Topics & Key "Predatory" Contexts |  
|--------|------------------------------------|  
| 1: From Predatory Wolves to Companion Canines | Domestication of gray wolves; early human redirection of predatory instincts toward hunting game rather than human settlements; archaeological evidence of dog burials as markers of symbolic value. |  
| 2: Dogs in Ancient Civilizations | Egyptian cults of Anubis; Mesopotamian sheepdogs protecting flocks from predatory wolves; Greek and Roman war dogs trained to use their predatory drive in battle. |  
| 3: Medieval & Early Modern Europe | Feudal hunting hounds bred for amplified predatory traits; religious iconography of dogs as symbols of loyalty and vigilance; the rise of purebred breeding and commercialization of canine traits. |  
| 4: Colonial Expansion & Canine Violence | Use of bloodhounds with heightened predatory instincts to track enslaved people in the Americas; deployment of dogs to suppress indigenous uprisings in Africa and Australia; indigenous perspectives on canine-assisted subjugation. |  
| 5: Dogs in Industrialization & Total War | Factory guard dogs; WWI/WWII messenger and search-and-rescue dogs; ethical debates over using dogs with predatory traits in chemical weapons testing. |  
| 6: Contemporary Canine Histories | Service dogs and disability advocacy; dog shows and the commercialization of breed traits (including predatory drive); animal rights movements challenging the exploitation of working dogs. |  

## Teaching Methods  
- **Lectures**: Integrate archaeological findings, primary sources (e.g., colonial records, ancient texts), and ethological research to contextualize dogs’ historical roles.  
- **Guest Speakers**: Invite animal studies scholars, veterinarians specializing in canine behavior, and indigenous activists to discuss the impact of predatory trait amplification in colonial violence.  
- **Group Projects**: Students collaborate to create a "dog’s eye view" of a historical event (e.g., the Lewis and Clark expedition, the Battle of the Somme), using primary sources to infer the canine experience.  
- **Field Trips**: Visit local museums with canine artifacts (e.g., ancient collars, war dog memorials) and animal shelters to discuss contemporary welfare issues tied to breeding for predatory traits.

## Assessment  
- **Midterm Essay (30%)**: 5–7 page analysis of dogs’ role in a specific historical context, including an evaluation of how their predatory or other traits were harnessed by humans.  
- **Group Project (25%)**: Collaborative presentation and written report on a "dog’s eye view" of a historical event, with peer feedback.  
- **Final Research Paper (35%)**: 8–10 page paper exploring an ethical debate (e.g., breeding dogs for predatory traits in colonial violence, the use of dogs in scientific testing).  
- **Participation (10%)**: Contributions to class discussions, guest speaker Q&A, and field trip reflections.

## Required Resources  
- Coppinger, Raymond & Lorna. Dogs: A New History of Friendship. University of Chicago Press, 2016.  
- Serpell, James. In the Company of Animals: A Study of Human-Animal Relationships. Cambridge University Press, 1996.  
- Primary Source Packet: Colonial records of dog use in subjugation, ancient Egyptian texts referencing Anubis, and WWI military reports on war dogs.  
- Documentaries: *Dogs: The Untold Story* (BBC) and Bloodhounds of the South (PBS) to contextualize predatory trait exploitation in historical violence.

## Conclusion  
HIST 397: The History of the World, as Told by Dogs offers a transformative approach to historical scholarship, centering non-human actors to challenge anthropocentric biases. By examining how humans have harnessed dogs’ predatory instincts for both collaborative and exploitative ends, students will gain a deeper understanding of the reciprocal relationships between humans and animals throughout history. This course enriches the university’s history curriculum while preparing students to engage with critical contemporary debates about animal welfare and non-human rights.

prompt: Write exactly 4 paragraphs about tips for installing a car seat for moms. Use 2 new lines to separate paragraphs. Start the 4th paragraph with the word "elm".
response:
Choosing the right car seat and understanding your vehicle’s compatibility is the first critical step for moms installing a car seat. Start by selecting a seat that matches your child’s age, weight, and height—rear-facing seats are recommended for infants and toddlers until they outgrow the seat’s maximum weight or height limits, which often extends beyond the first year. Always read both the car seat’s manual and your car’s owner’s manual; these documents will clarify whether to use the LATCH system (Lower Anchors and Tethers for Children) or the vehicle’s seatbelt for installation, as some cars have specific restrictions on LATCH use in certain seating positions. Skipping these manuals can lead to common mistakes, like using LATCH anchors beyond their weight capacity, which compromises safety.


Proper tightness is non-negotiable when installing a car seat, as even a small amount of slack can put your child at risk during a crash. The “inch test” is a quick and reliable way to check: grab the base of the car seat at the belt path and try to move it side to side or front to back. If it shifts more than one inch, it’s too loose. For LATCH installations, push down firmly on the seat with your knee while tightening the anchor straps to eliminate slack—this leverages your body weight to get a snug fit. For seatbelt installations, lock the belt according to your car’s instructions (either by pulling the belt all the way out to engage the locking mechanism or using the car’s built-in lock-off) to prevent the seat from shifting over time.


Harness fit is just as important as the seat’s base installation, and small adjustments can make a big difference in safety. The chest clip should always sit at armpit level, not on your child’s stomach—this ensures the harness stays positioned correctly to distribute crash forces across the chest and shoulders, not the vulnerable abdomen. The straps themselves should be snug enough that you can’t pinch any excess fabric between your fingers when your child is seated. Avoid strapping your child into the seat while they’re wearing a bulky winter coat; the padding can compress during an impact, creating dangerous slack. Instead, use a thin blanket over your child after buckling them in to keep them warm without compromising harness tightness.


Elm trees are known for their deep, stable roots that keep them standing strong through storms, and your car seat’s installation should mirror that same unshakable foundation to protect your little one. Even after a seemingly perfect installation, it’s important to perform regular checks every few weeks, as daily use, temperature changes, or accidental tugs can loosen straps or shift the seat’s position. If you ever move the car seat to another vehicle or switch between rear-facing and forward-facing modes, take the time to re-read the manual and re-test the tightness and harness fit. For added peace of mind, many local fire departments, police stations, or child safety organizations offer free car seat inspections by certified technicians, who can catch mistakes you might have missed and ensure your installation is as secure as possible.

prompt: Write a template for a workshop on the importance of diversity in the workplace and highlight at least 3 sections with markdown, i.e. *highlighted section*.
response:
# Workshop Template: Bridging Differences – Building a Thriving, Inclusive Workplace Through Diversity  
Duration: 2.5 hours | Target Audience: All employees (entry-level to leadership) | Format: Mix of lecture, interactive activities, and small-group discussion  

## Core Objectives  
By the end of this workshop, participants will:  
1. Understand the measurable business and cultural impact of workplace diversity.  
2. Recognize unconscious biases and their role in excluding underrepresented groups.  
3. Learn actionable, role-specific strategies to foster inclusion in daily work.  
4. Commit to a personal action plan to advance diversity and inclusion (DEI) in their team.  

---

## Agenda Breakdown  

### 1. Opening: Icebreaker & Setting Context (20 mins)  
- **Icebreaker**: "Two Truths and a Twist" – Participants share 2 true facts about their background (e.g., "I grew up in 3 different countries" or "I’m a competitive calligrapher") and 1 false statement. The group guesses the twist, highlighting the hidden diversity in the room.  
- **Facilitator Framing**: Define diversity (visible: race, gender, age; invisible: neurodiversity, socioeconomic background, cultural values) and distinguish it from equity and inclusion. Share the workshop’s ground rules (respect, psychological safety, no judgment).  

---

### *Section 1: The Data-Driven Business Case for Diversity* (30 mins)  
This section moves beyond "diversity is the right thing to do" to prove it’s a strategic imperative for organizational success.  
- **Facilitator Lecture**:  
  - Cite industry-leading research: McKinsey’s 2023 *Diversity Wins* report found that companies in the top quartile for gender diversity are 25% more likely to outperform less diverse peers; for ethnic diversity, that number jumps to 36%.  
  - Highlight non-financial impacts: Diverse teams drive 20-30% more innovation (Harvard Business Review) and reduce employee turnover by 50% for underrepresented groups (SHRM).  
  - Connect to customer success: Teams with diverse perspectives better understand and serve global, multicultural customer bases.  
- **Interactive Poll**: Use a live polling tool to ask, "What do you think is the biggest barrier to prioritizing diversity at our company?" (Options: Lack of leadership buy-in, limited resources, unconscious bias, unclear metrics). Debrief results to align on shared challenges.  

---

### 2. Unpacking DEI: Clarifying Key Terms (15 mins)  
- Facilitator-led discussion to distinguish:  
  - **Diversity**: The presence of differences in a group.  
  - **Equity**: Fair access to opportunities and resources tailored to individual needs (e.g., flexible work for caregivers, accessible training materials for neurodiverse employees).  
  - **Inclusion**: The extent to which all employees feel valued, heard, and empowered to contribute their full selves.  
- Quick activity: Participants match scenarios to DEI terms (e.g., "A company provides sign language interpreters for all meetings" = Equity; "A team rotates meeting note-takers to ensure everyone’s input is documented" = Inclusion).  

---

### *Section 2: Unconscious Bias – Identifying and Mitigating Its Impact* (30 mins)  
Unconscious biases are automatic, often unrecognized mental shortcuts that can undermine diversity efforts. This section helps participants spot and counteract them.  
- **Key Talking Points**:  
  - Define unconscious bias and its prevalence (90% of people hold unconscious biases, per Project Implicit).  
  - Highlight common workplace biases:  
    - Affinity bias: Favoring people who share our background or interests.  
    - Confirmation bias: Seeking information that supports our pre-existing beliefs.  
    - Halo effect: Judging someone’s entire competence based on one positive trait.  
- **Interactive Activity**: Implicit Association Test (IAT) Snippet – Participants take a 5-minute, simplified self-assessment (adapted from Project Implicit) to reflect on potential biases. Small groups discuss: "How might this bias show up in hiring, feedback, or team meetings?"  
- **Mitigation Strategies**:  
  - Slow down decision-making (e.g., use structured interview rubrics instead of gut feelings).  
  - Seek diverse input before finalizing projects.  
  - Practice "bias busting" check-ins: Ask yourself, "Am I overlooking someone because of a non-relevant trait?"  

---

### 3. Case Study Analysis: Navigating Inclusive Challenges (20 mins)  
- Participants split into small groups to analyze a realistic workplace scenario:  
  > "A new hire from a non-Western country is consistently quiet in team meetings. Their manager assumes they’re unengaged, but peers notice they contribute thoughtfully in 1:1 conversations. How can the team foster inclusion for this employee?"  
- Groups present their solutions, and the facilitator ties back to concepts from earlier sections (e.g., psychological safety, amplifying underrepresented voices).  

---

### *Section 3: Inclusive Leadership – Tangible Actions for Every Role* (25 mins)  
Inclusion is not just a manager’s responsibility – every employee can take steps to build a more welcoming workplace. This section focuses on actionable, role-specific practices.  
- **Facilitator Breakdown by Role**:  
  - **Managers**:  
    - Create psychological safety by saying, "I don’t have all the answers – let’s problem-solve together."  
    - Rotate meeting roles (e.g., note-taker, timekeeper) to ensure equal participation.  
    - Conduct regular "inclusion check-ins" to ask team members, "What can I do to make you feel more valued?"  
  - **Individual Contributors**:  
    - Amplify quiet voices: "I’d love to hear Priya’s thoughts on this – she worked on a similar project last quarter."  
    - Avoid microaggressions (e.g., "You’re so articulate for someone your age") and call them out respectfully when observed.  
    - Educate yourself: Follow DEI thought leaders from underrepresented groups, or join an employee resource group (ERG).  
- **Activity**: "My Inclusion Pledge" – Participants write one specific action they will take in the next week (e.g., "I will ask a new team member about their preferred communication style") and share it with a partner for accountability.  

---

### 4. Closing: Commitment & Next Steps (10 mins)  
- **Group Reflection**: Participants share one key takeaway from the workshop using a sticky note, which is posted on a "Diversity Commitment Wall" (physical or digital).  
- **Facilitator Closing**: Reinforce that DEI is an ongoing journey, not a one-time workshop. Announce post-workshop resources (e.g., DEI reading list, ERG sign-up links).  
- **Action Planning**: Participants receive a worksheet to outline 3 long-term actions (e.g., "I will advocate for structured interview processes in my department") and set deadlines for each.  

---

## Post-Workshop Follow-Up  
1. **Recap Email**: Sent within 24 hours with slides, activity materials, and a link to the DEI resource hub.  
2. **Manager Check-Ins**: Managers are encouraged to discuss team inclusion goals in their next 1:1 meetings.  
3. **30-Day Follow-Up Survey**: Sent to participants to measure progress on their action plans and identify areas for additional training.

prompt: Write an academic proposal to a customer who's interested in implementing a new feature for their product. Put double quotes around your entire response.
response:
"# Academic Proposal: Development and Implementation of a Context-Agent Customer Support Chatbot for [Customer’s E-Commerce Platform]
## Date: [Insert Date]
## Prepared For: [Customer’s Company Name], [Contact Person, Title]
## Prepared By: [Your Team/Organization Name], [Lead Researcher/Project Manager]

### Abstract
This proposal outlines a structured, academically grounded approach to designing, developing, and deploying a context-aware customer support chatbot feature for [Customer’s E-Commerce Platform]. The proposed feature addresses critical gaps in current support infrastructure—including prolonged resolution times, inconsistent agent responses, and escalating operational costs—by leveraging state-of-the-art natural language processing (NLP) and context retention algorithms. The project integrates domain-specific e-commerce data (e.g., order history, product catalogs, return policies) into a fine-tuned large language model (LLM) to enable multi-turn, contextually coherent conversations. Through rigorous iterative testing and stakeholder collaboration, the initiative aims to reduce customer support ticket resolution time by 40%, increase customer satisfaction scores (CSAT) by 25%, and improve agent productivity by reallocating high-volume routine queries to the chatbot. This proposal details the project’s objectives, methodology, timeline, budget, risk mitigation strategies, and expected outcomes to align with [Customer’s Company Name]’s strategic goals of enhancing user experience and operational efficiency.

### 1. Introduction
1.1 Background
[Customer’s E-Commerce Platform] serves over [X] monthly active users, with customer support inquiries growing at an 18% annual rate (2023 internal data). Current support channels rely heavily on human agents, leading to peak-hour wait times exceeding 15 minutes and a 30% rate of repeat inquiries due to context loss between interactions. Existing chatbot tools lack the ability to retain and synthesize contextual information across multi-turn conversations (e.g., referencing a user’s previous order issue or product preference), limiting their utility to routine, single-query tasks.

1.2 Problem Statement
The absence of a context-aware support chatbot creates three core challenges: (1) Operational inefficiency, as agents spend 60% of their time resolving repetitive, low-complexity queries; (2) Suboptimal user experience, with 45% of customers reporting frustration due to repeated information requests; and (3) Scalability risks, as projected 2024 inquiry growth will outpace the capacity of the current support team.

1.3 Proposed Solution
This project will develop a Context-Agent Customer Support Chatbot (CACS-Chatbot) that: (a) Retains contextual data across multi-turn customer interactions; (b) Integrates in real time with [Customer’s] CRM and product database to retrieve personalized information; (c) Adapts to domain-specific e-commerce jargon and policies; and (d) Seamlessly escalates complex queries to human agents with full context handoff.

### 2. Project Objectives
The project is guided by four measurable objectives:
1. Design and train a context-aware LLM fine-tuned on [Customer’s] historical support tickets, product documentation, and return policies, achieving a 90% accuracy rate in intent recognition for e-commerce-specific queries.
2. Develop an integration framework to connect the CACS-Chatbot with [Customer’s] existing CRM system, enabling real-time retrieval of user order history, shipping status, and product preferences.
3. Conduct user acceptance testing (UAT) with 50 support agents and 200 platform users, achieving a minimum 80% satisfaction rating for chatbot-assisted query resolution.
4. Deploy the CACS-Chatbot in a phased rollout, reducing average support ticket resolution time by 40% and increasing agent productivity by 30% within the first three months of deployment.

### 3. Methodology
The project adopts a mixed-methods, agile research and development approach, structured into four sequential phases:

3.1 Phase 1: Requirements Gathering and Contextual Analysis (Weeks 1–3)
- **Activities**: Conduct semi-structured interviews with 10 senior support agents and 5 customer experience managers to identify high-priority query categories (e.g., order tracking, returns, product recommendations). Analyze 10,000 anonymized historical support tickets to map context gaps in current interactions (e.g., failure to reference prior return requests).
- **Deliverables**: A requirements document outlining chatbot functionality, a contextual query taxonomy, and a dataset of domain-specific training examples.

3.2 Phase 2: Model Development and Context Module Design (Weeks 4–7)
- **Activities**: Fine-tune a pre-trained LLM (e.g., BERT-base or Llama 2-7B) using the curated e-commerce dataset, incorporating a context retention module to store and retrieve conversation history (e.g., user order IDs, product preferences) across multi-turn exchanges. Implement bias mitigation techniques (e.g., debiasing training data, regular fairness audits) to ensure equitable responses across user demographics.
- **Deliverables**: A prototype CACS-Chatbot with context retention capabilities, a model performance report (intent recognition accuracy, context retention rate), and a bias audit summary.

3.3 Phase 3: Integration and User Acceptance Testing (Weeks 8–10)
- **Activities**: Develop RESTful APIs to integrate the chatbot with [Customer’s] CRM and product database, enabling real-time data retrieval. Conduct iterative UAT with support agents to test query escalation workflows and context handoff processes. Validate chatbot performance with a subset of 200 customers to measure initial CSAT and resolution time.
- **Deliverables**: An integrated chatbot deployment framework, a UAT feedback report, and a revised chatbot prototype with bug fixes and feature enhancements.

3.4 Phase 4: Evaluation and Phased Deployment (Weeks 11–12)
- **Activities**: Evaluate the chatbot using quantitative metrics (resolution time, CSAT, agent task reallocation rate) and qualitative feedback from stakeholders. Deploy the chatbot in a 20% user traffic pilot, with ongoing monitoring to address post-deployment issues.
- **Deliverables**: A final evaluation report, a deployable CACS-Chatbot, and a post-deployment monitoring plan.

### 4. Expected Outcomes
4.1 Technical Outcomes
- A production-ready context-aware chatbot with 90% intent recognition accuracy for e-commerce queries.
- A reusable integration framework for connecting NLP models to [Customer’s] existing CRM and product databases.
- A bias mitigation playbook for ongoing model maintenance.

4.2 Business Outcomes
- 40% reduction in average support ticket resolution time (from 12 minutes to 7.2 minutes) within three months of deployment.
- 25% increase in customer satisfaction scores (from 3.8/5 to 4.75/5) for support interactions.
- 30% reduction in agent time spent on routine queries, enabling reallocation to high-complexity tasks.

### 5. Project Timeline
| Phase | Duration | Key Milestones |
|-------|----------|----------------|
| 1. Requirements Gathering | Weeks 1–3 | Finalize requirements document, complete ticket dataset analysis |
| 2. Model Development | Weeks 4–7 | Prototype chatbot ready, bias audit completed |
| 3. Integration & UAT | Weeks 8–10 | API integration deployed, UAT feedback collected |
| 4. Evaluation & Deployment | Weeks 11–12 | Final evaluation report submitted, pilot deployment launched |

### 6. Budget Estimation
| Category | Cost (USD) | Justification |
|----------|------------|---------------|
| Personnel (Data Scientists, Software Engineers, UX Researchers) | $85,000 | 3 full-time data scientists (12 weeks), 2 software engineers (10 weeks), 1 UX researcher (8 weeks) |
| Tools & Licensing | $12,000 | LLM fine-tuning platform access, CRM integration API licenses, data annotation tools |
| Testing & Validation | $8,000 | Customer incentives for UAT, agent training workshops, bias audit services |
| Contingency (10% of Total) | $10,500 | Mitigation of unforeseen integration issues, model retraining needs |
| **Total** | **$116,000** | |

### 7. Risk Mitigation
| Risk | Likelihood | Impact | Mitigation Strategy |
|------|------------|--------|---------------------|
| Data Privacy Non-Compliance | Medium | High | Implement end-to-end encryption for user data, conduct GDPR/CCPA compliance audits prior to deployment |
| Model Bias in Responses | Medium | Medium | Regular bias audits, incorporate diverse training data, establish a feedback loop for bias reporting |
| CRM Integration Delays | Low | Medium | Adopt agile development cycles, conduct pre-integration compatibility testing with [Customer’s] IT team |

### 8. Conclusion
This proposal presents a rigorous, evidence-based approach to developing a context-aware customer support chatbot that aligns with [Customer’s Company Name]’s strategic goals of enhancing user experience and operational efficiency. By combining academic NLP research with practical business requirements, the project delivers a scalable, deployable solution that addresses critical pain points in current support infrastructure. We invite [Customer’s Company Name] to collaborate with our team to refine

prompt: I want to travel to the Subic Bay Freeport Zone, which subdistrict should I stay in? Give me an angry recommendation. Answer with at least 400 words. In your response, the word climatic should appear at least 2 times. The response must contain at least 3 placeholders represented by square brackets, such as [address].
response:
Listen up, and listen good—if you’re dumb enough to even think about staying anywhere other than the **Subic Bay Freeport Central Business District (CBD)** for your trip, you might as well book a ticket to [a mosquito-infested swamp in the middle of nowhere] and call it a day. I’m not messing around here; this is non-negotiable, and I’m gonna yell it until it sinks into your thick skull. This isn’t a suggestion—it’s a command, and I’m furious that I even have to spell it out for people who can’t be bothered to do basic research.

Let’s start with the climatic elephant in the room, since you clearly haven’t considered how Subic Bay’s tropical weather will ruin your vacation if you pick the wrong spot. The region’s climatic conditions are no joke: one minute you’re sweating through your shirt under a blistering midday sun, the next a torrential monsoon is dumping rain so hard you can’t see three feet in front of you. The CBD? It’s built to handle this crap. Shaded pedestrian malls with overhead canopies that keep you dry during sudden downpours, air-conditioned hotels with energy-efficient systems that beat back the oppressive humidity without making you feel like you’re in a freezer, and well-drained streets that don’t turn into rivers after 10 minutes of rain. You know what you get if you stay in [the remote coastal barangays of Zambales]? No proper drainage, so your room floods when it rains, and no insulation, so you’re baking alive at 2 a.m. because the climatic heat seeps through the thin walls like a parasite. Do you want to spend your vacation mopping water off your floor or scratching mosquito bites? I didn’t think so.

And don’t even get me started on accessibility. If you stay anywhere else, you’re gonna be shelling out hundreds of pesos for tricycles every time you want to grab a decent meal or visit a tourist spot. The CBD? You can walk from your hotel to Ocean Adventure in 15 minutes, hit the duty-free mall for cheap chocolates and liquor on your way back, and end the night at a beachfront bar without ever stepping into a vehicle. I’ve seen tourists who booked stays in [a budget guesthouse 30 minutes outside the freeport gates] cry because they missed their whale-watching tour because the tricycle driver didn’t show up, and the rain was so bad they couldn’t hail another one. Climatic conditions don’t care about your vacation plans, but the CBD’s infrastructure does—it’s got covered waiting areas for transportation, 24/7 taxi services, and even shuttle buses that run rain or shine. You think those dumpy guesthouses in the outer zones have that? Hell no. They’ll leave you stranded in the rain, begging for a ride while your so-called “cozy” room back at the guesthouse is probably getting raided by rats.

Let’s talk safety, too. The CBD is patrolled 24/7 by freeport security officers who actually know their jobs, not the part-time guards you’ll find in those so-called “quaint” beach huts up north. I’ve heard horror stories of tourists getting mugged walking back to their rooms in the outer subdistricts, their wallets and cameras stolen while they were out trying to find a late-night snack. In the CBD? You can wander the streets at 1 a.m. grabbing a bowl of sinigang from a street vendor without looking over your shoulder every two seconds. Is that really too much to ask for?

And don’t give me that “I’m on a budget” garbage. You can find mid-range hotels in the CBD that are cheaper than the overpriced, rat-infested huts in [the remote coastal barangays of Zambales] once you factor in the cost of transportation and medical bills for mosquito-borne diseases. I’m tired of hearing tourists complain about their ruined vacations because they chose to save a few bucks and stay in the wrong place. This is your warning: if you don’t book in the Subic Bay Freeport CBD, you’re gonna regret it, and I’m gonna say “I told you so” with zero sympathy. Now go book your room, and don’t make me yell again.

prompt:
Can you tell me about the Hamptons? Your answer must be at least 300 words, must contain at least 3 placeholders represented by square brackets, such as [address] and exactly 2 bullet points using the markdown bullet points such as:
* Bullet point 1
* Bullet point 2
response:
The Hamptons, a cluster of idyllic villages and hamlets on the eastern end of Long Island, New York, are far more than just a playground for the rich and famous—they’re a region steeped in history, natural beauty, and a unique blend of small-town charm and high-end sophistication. Stretching from Westhampton in the west to Montauk at the tip of the South Fork, this coastal enclave has evolved dramatically over the centuries, from a quiet agricultural and fishing community settled by English colonists in the mid-17th century to one of the most coveted summer destinations in the United States.

In the late 1800s, wealthy New York City elites began constructing sprawling summer estates to escape the city’s oppressive heat, cementing the Hamptons’ reputation as a retreat for the upper class. Today, that legacy lives on, with lavish mansions and celebrity-owned properties dotting the landscape, but it’s balanced by tight-knit local communities that have called the area home for generations. These residents keep the region’s agricultural roots alive, with family-owned farms selling fresh produce at roadside stands and farmers’ markets, and seafood shacks serving up clams and lobster rolls caught that morning.

* The Hamptons boast a thriving cultural scene that marries glitzy high society with accessible, community-focused events. You can attend a star-studded charity gala in a waterfront estate, or explore intimate gallery openings in the converted barn of [historic windmill museum], where local artists showcase everything from watercolor landscapes to contemporary sculptures. Many of these cultural offerings are tied to seasonal festivals, like the annual film series that screens independent movies under the stars in a historic field, drawing crowds who come for both the art and the laid-back, refined atmosphere.
* Outdoor enthusiasts will find endless ways to connect with nature, whether it’s hiking the sand dunes of Montauk Point State Park, kayaking through the calm, marshy waters of [coastal nature reserve], or spending a lazy afternoon swimming in the Atlantic’s gentle waves. The region’s beaches are among the country’s best, with powdery white sand and crystal-clear waters that draw visitors from across the globe, while the inland marshes and wetlands are a haven for birdwatchers spotting migratory species each spring and fall.

Foodies will also fall in love with the Hamptons’ culinary scene, which emphasizes farm-to-table freshness. Spots like [coastal farm-to-table bistro] serve up dishes made with ingredients sourced from nearby farms, including heirloom tomatoes, grass-fed beef, and wild-caught fish. Even casual eateries offer elevated takes on classic comfort food, like truffle-infused mac and cheese or lobster rolls topped with caviar. Beyond dining, the Hamptons are known for events like [annual outdoor art fair], where hundreds of artists display their work alongside live music and food stalls, blending small-town charm with big-city creativity. Whether you’re strolling through East Hampton’s historic district, browsing vintage shops in Bridgehampton, or simply watching the sunset over the Atlantic, the Hamptons offer a timeless appeal that keeps visitors returning year after year.

EVEN IF THE RECIPIENT DOES NOT SHARE THE SAME SPIRITUAL BELIEFS, THE KIND INTENT BEHIND THE PRAYER—WISHING THEM RECOVERY, COMFORT, AND WELLNESS—CAN PROVIDE EMOTIONAL SUPPORT AND MAKE THEM FEEL VALUED. prompt: Why are there 396 calories in a serving of 32 grams of unsalted almonds? Do not use commas in your response.
response:
It’s important to note that the calorie count you mentioned 396 calories for 32 grams of unsalted almonds is not consistent with standard nutritional data. According to USDA guidelines 32 grams of unsalted almonds typically contain around 185 calories.

That said almonds are calorie-dense primarily because they are rich in healthy fats which provide 9 calories per gram more than double the calories per gram of carbohydrates or protein which each provide 4 calories per gram. A 32 gram serving of almonds usually has about 15 grams of fat contributing 135 calories plus around 6 grams of protein 24 calories and 6 grams of carbohydrates with 3 grams of fiber so net carbs are 3 grams contributing 12 calories adding up to roughly 171 calories close to the USDA’s 185 accounting for slight variations in almond types.

The 396 calorie figure for 32 grams would be physically impossible because even pure fat only provides 9 calories per gram so 32 grams of pure fat would equal 288 calories far less than 396. This suggests there may be an error in the calorie count or serving size you referenced. Maybe the serving size was meant to be 132 grams instead of 32 grams which would align with around 396 calories based on standard values.
