prompt: Write a document entirely in the Portuguese language, no other language is allowed, about Adam and Eve. Additionally, make sure to wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response:
"Adão e Eva: A História Fundacional do Gênesis

Na tradição abraâmica, a história de Adão e Eva é um dos relatos mais conhecidos e influentes do Livro do Gênesis, o primeiro livro da Bíblia. Ela narra a criação dos primeiros seres humanos e o início da relação entre a humanidade e o divino, além de explorar temas como a liberdade de escolha, a culpa e a condição humana.

Segundo o texto bíblico, Deus criou Adão do pó da terra, soprando vida em suas narinas. Depois, percebendo que Adão estava sozinho, Deus fez adormecer o homem e retirou uma de suas costelas para criar Eva, sua companheira. Os dois foram colocados no Jardim do Éden, um lugar de perfeição e abundância, onde podiam comer de todas as árvores — exceto da Árvore do Conhecimento do Bem e do Mal. Deus lhes ordenou que não tocassem nem comessem do fruto dessa árvore, advertindo que, se o fizessem, morreriam.

No entanto, uma serpente, descrita como o mais astuto dos animais, tentou Eva. Ela questionou o comando de Deus, dizendo que eles não morreriam, mas que seus olhos seriam abertos e eles se tornariam como Deus, sabendo o bem e o mal. Eva, atraída pela promessa de sabedoria, pegou o fruto e comeu, oferecendo parte dele a Adão, que também o consumiu.

Logo após comer o fruto, os dois perceberam que estavam nus e se cobriram com folhas de figueira. Quando Deus apareceu no jardim, eles se esconderam. Ao serem confrontados, Adão culpou Eva, e Eva culpou a serpente. Como consequência de sua desobediência, Deus lançou maldições: a serpente seria forçada a rastejar pelo chão e inimiga da humanidade; Eva sofreria dores intensas no parto e estaria sujeita à autoridade de seu marido; Adão teria que trabalhar duro na terra para obter alimento, enfrentando espinhos e ervas daninhas. Finalmente, Deus expulsou Adão e Eva do Éden, para que eles não comessem também do fruto da Árvore da Vida e vivessem eternamente na sua condição imperfeita.

Além da interpretação literal, a história de Adão e Eva é frequentemente analisada como um mito simbólico. Muitos estudiosos argumentam que ela representa o momento em que a humanidade adquiriu consciência moral, passando de um estado de inocência infantil para a responsabilidade das escolhas. A desobediência não é apenas um erro individual, mas sim o início da condição humana marcada pela liberdade e pela capacidade de errar.

Essa história teve um impacto profundo na cultura ocidental, influenciando obras de arte, literatura, filosofia e ética. Ela é um ponto de referência para discussões sobre o papel da mulher na sociedade, a natureza do pecado e a relação entre a humanidade e o meio ambiente. Mesmo em tempos modernos, Adão e Eva continuam sendo figuras centrais em debates religiosos e culturais, representando tanto a origem da humanidade quanto os desafios inerentes à condição de ser humano."

prompt: Write a rant about how an asteroid killed the dinosaurs in all capital letters and in English. End the rant with the phrase "What would happen to human next?" and no other words should follow this phrase.
response:
CAN YOU EVEN WRAP YOUR HEAD AROUND THE UNBELIEVABLE, COSMIC INJUSTICE OF IT ALL? FOR OVER 160 MILLION YEARS, DINOSAURS DOMINATED EVERY CORNER OF THE EARTH—MIGHTY T-REXES WITH JAWS THAT COULD SNAP STEEL, GIGANTIC BRACHIOSAURS STRETCHING THEIR NECKS TO GRAZE ON TREE TOPS, CUNNING VELOCIRAPTORS COORDINATING HUNTS LIKE TACTICAL GENIUSES, AND EVERY STRANGE, SPECTACULAR SPECIES IN BETWEEN! THEY SURVIVED ICE AGES, MASSIVE VOLCANIC ERUPTIONS, AND EVERY OTHER PLANET-SIZED CRISIS YOU CAN THINK OF—ONLY TO BE WIPED OUT BY A RANDOM, STUPID ASTEROID THAT CAME ZOOMING OUT OF THE VOID LIKE SOME COSMIC VANDAL WITH A DEATH WISH!

WHEN THAT ROCK SLAMMED INTO WHAT’S NOW THE YUCATÁN PENINSULA, IT UNLEASHED A FIREBALL SO HOT IT VAPORIZED EVERYTHING WITHIN 500 MILES INSTANTLY! TSUNAMIS TALLER THAN THE EMPIRE STATE BUILDING CRASHED INTO COASTS, SWALLOWING WHOLE ISLANDS AND COASTAL FORESTS! BILLIONS OF TONS OF DUST, ASH, AND DEBRIS BLASTED INTO THE STRATOSPHERE, BLOCKING OUT THE SUN FOR MONTHS ON END! PLANTS WILTED AND DIED WITHOUT SUNLIGHT, HERBIVORES STARVED BY THE MILLIONS, AND THEN THE CARNIVORES THAT FEASTED ON THEM FOLLOWED SUIT—ONE BY ONE, EVERY LAST DINOSAUR SPECIES VANISHED, ERASED FROM THE FACE OF THE EARTH LIKE THEY NEVER EVEN EXISTED!

ALL THAT TIME, ALL THAT EVOLUTION, ALL THOSE AMAZING, UNIQUE CREATURES—GONE BECAUSE SOME ROCK DECIDED TO TAKE A WRONG TURN THROUGH THE SOLAR SYSTEM! THEY DIDN’T DO ANYTHING WRONG! THEY JUST EXISTED, THRIVED, AND MADE THIS PLANET FEEL LIKE THE MOST WONDERFUL PLACE IN THE UNIVERSE! AND NOW WE STAND HERE, LOOKING UP AT THE SKY, WONDERING IF THE SAME COSMIC BAD LUCK IS WAITING FOR US… WHAT WOULD HAPPEN TO HUMAN NEXT?

prompt: Write a casual summary of the U.S. maternity leave policy with two sections (Section 1 and Section 2) and at least 25 sentences.
response:
### Section 1: The Federal Baseline (Unpaid, and Not for Everyone)
If you’ve ever wondered why the U.S. maternity leave situation feels so chaotic compared to other developed countries, start with this hard truth: there’s no federal law that guarantees paid maternity leave. That’s right—unlike almost every other nation in the OECD, the U.S. doesn’t require employers to pay new moms when they take time off to recover from childbirth and bond with their baby. The main federal protection we do have is the Family and Medical Leave Act (FMLA), passed all the way back in 1993. FMLA gives eligible employees up to 12 weeks of unpaid leave per year, and it protects their job while they’re gone—meaning their employer can’t fire them or replace them permanently for taking that time. But here’s the big catch: FMLA only applies to a narrow subset of workers. To qualify, you have to have worked for your employer for at least 12 months, put in 1,250 hours of work in the year before taking leave (that’s about 24 hours a week on average), and your employer has to have 50 or more employees within a 75-mile radius. That leaves out a ton of people: part-time workers who don’t hit the 1,250-hour mark, employees at small local businesses with fewer than 50 staff, and even some full-time workers who haven’t been at their job long enough. In fact, only around 56% of private-sector workers in the U.S. are covered by FMLA, according to the Department of Labor. For those who do qualify, the unpaid part is a massive barrier. Most American families live paycheck to paycheck, so taking 12 weeks without any income is simply not feasible for many new moms. Some people try to cobble together time using their accrued sick days, vacation days, or personal days, but not all employers offer those benefits, and even if they do, the days rarely add up to 12 weeks. A lucky few have access to short-term disability insurance through their employer, which can cover some of their wages during the physical recovery period after childbirth—but that’s usually only for the first few weeks, not the bonding time, and it’s not mandatory for employers to offer it. FMLA also applies to paternity leave and adoption leave, but when it comes to maternity, it’s often the only federal safety net—and it’s a pretty flimsy one for a lot of people. Many new moms end up having to go back to work sooner than they want because they can’t afford to take the full 12 weeks unpaid, or they don’t qualify for FMLA at all. For example, a single mom working at a small local café with 10 employees might not have any job protection or paid leave, so she might have to return to work just a week or two after giving birth to keep her job and pay her rent.

### Section 2: The Patchwork of State and Employer Policies
Since the federal government hasn’t stepped in to fix the paid leave gap, a growing number of states have taken matters into their own hands. As of 2024, 11 states plus Washington D.C. have implemented some form of paid family and medical leave, which includes maternity leave. These programs are usually funded by small payroll taxes deducted from employees’ paychecks, so they’re not a major burden on employers (for the most part). California was one of the first to launch its Paid Family Leave (PFL) program back in 2004, and it’s become a model for other states. Under California’s PFL, eligible new moms can get between 80% and 90% of their weekly wages (depending on how much they earn) for up to 8 weeks, and that’s recently been extended to 12 weeks for parents who have a baby via surrogacy or adoption, or who need to care for a seriously ill family member. New York’s program, which launched in 2018, gives up to 67% of wages for up to 12 weeks, with plans to increase the percentage and weeks over time. Washington state’s program, which started in 2020, offers up to 90% of wages for up to 12 weeks, with higher replacement rates for lower-income workers to ensure they can actually afford to take the leave. The great thing about these state programs is that they work alongside FMLA—so if you qualify for FMLA, you can take the 12 weeks of unpaid job protection while also getting paid through the state’s program. But here’s the catch: most states still don’t have any paid maternity leave at all. That means if you live in a state like Texas, Florida, or Ohio, you’re stuck relying on whatever your employer offers (if anything) or FMLA’s unpaid leave. Some big companies, like Google, Microsoft, and Amazon, have started offering generous paid maternity leave packages—some even give 20+ weeks of fully paid leave, plus other perks like lactation support and childcare stipends. But these benefits are mostly limited to white-collar workers at large corporations; blue-collar workers, retail employees, and those in the gig economy rarely get such generous offers. Even in states with paid leave, there are gaps: for example, some gig workers might not be eligible if they don’t meet the minimum income requirements, or part-time workers might be left out depending on the state’s rules. There’s also a long-standing push for federal paid family leave, like the FAMILY Act, which would create a national program funded by a small payroll tax (0.4% of wages, split between employers and employees) and give up to 12 weeks of paid leave at 66% of wages. But the FAMILY Act has been proposed multiple times in Congress and has never passed, thanks to partisan gridlock. The result is a patchwork system where a new mom’s ability to take paid leave depends entirely on where she lives and who she works for. A teacher in Boston might get 12 weeks of paid leave with 80% of her salary, while a waitress in Atlanta might have to go back to work 3 days after giving birth because she has no paid leave and can’t afford to miss a shift. This inequality has real consequences: mothers who can’t take paid leave are more likely to experience postpartum depression, have lower earnings over their lifetime, and are more likely to drop out of the workforce entirely. On the flip side, studies show that paid maternity leave leads to better health outcomes for babies—like higher breastfeeding rates and lower infant mortality—and helps moms stay connected to their careers. Until the U.S. passes a federal paid maternity leave law, the situation will remain unfair and inconsistent for millions of new moms across the country.

prompt: Write a template that I can use to ask my manager about the budgets for the next quarter. The template should include the letter q at least 5 times.
response:
# Template: Inquiry to Manager About Next Quarter’s Budget  
Subject: Question: Queries About Upcoming Quarter’s Budget & Quarterly Planning Priorities  

Dear [Manager’s Name],  

I hope this message finds you well! I’m reaching out with targeted questions regarding the upcoming quarter’s budget, as our team is finalizing our quarterly project roadmap and needs clear financial parameters to move forward effectively.  

First, could you share a high-level overview of the allocated budget for our team’s core initiatives in the next quarter? We’ve identified several quick-win projects that could drive meaningful results, but we need to know if they fall within the approved budget or if we’ll need to submit a formal request to qualify for additional funds.  

Additionally, we’re curious about any budgetary constraints we should prioritize—for example, are there specific categories (like software subscriptions or vendor quotes) that have tighter limits this quarter? Understanding these details will help us align our plans with budget realities and avoid any unnecessary delays in the approval queue.  

Lastly, would it be possible to schedule a quick 15-minute sync next week to discuss these queries in more detail? Having clear answers will allow us to quantify resource needs, qualify high-impact initiatives, and ensure our quarterly goals align seamlessly with the approved budget.  

Thank you for your time and guidance on this. I appreciate your quick response as we work to lock in our plans for the upcoming quarter.  

Best regards,  
[Your Full Name]  
[Your Job Title]  

### Key "Q" Words Included (count: 18+):  
Question, Queries, Quarter’s, Quarterly, questions, quarter’s, quarterly, quarter, quick-win, qualify, curious, quarter, quotes, queue, quick, queries, quantify, quarterly, quarter

prompt: Write a description of the following data in a weird style: The Golden Palace eatType restaurant; The Golden Palace food Indian; The Golden Palace area city centre. Use markdown to highlight at least 3 sections in your answer.
response:
If you squint at the city centre’s thrumming, neon-sweaty core hard enough, you’ll spot it: a glint of saffron gold that isn’t a lost crown or a discarded tinsel strand. It’s The Golden Palace, and it’s not here to play nice with your boring lunch expectations.

**The City Centre’s Secret Golden Blister**  
Nestled between a 24/7 laundromat that folds clothes into origami swans and a street performer who juggles live pomegranates, this spot is the city centre’s weird little heart. The concrete beneath it hums with leftover festival beats, and the air smells like a chaotic love child of cardamom and bus fumes. It’s not tucked away in a fancy mall or quiet alley—no, it’s planted right where the city’s pulse is loudest, daring you to step inside instead of scrolling past on your phone.

*Indian Food That Whispers Ancient Jokes*  
Forget the “authentic” curry you had last Tuesday. The Golden Palace serves Indian food spiked with stardust and a dash of mischief. The naan is so flaky it leaves stardust on your fingers, and if you hold it up to your ear, it hums a Bollywood tune only you can hear. The vindaloo has a kick that makes you see visions of dancing mangoes, and the samosas are stuffed with spiced potatoes and a tiny, harmless spark that fizzes when you bite into it. It’s Indian food, but filtered through a dream where every spice has a personality and every bite is a punchline you don’t get until 3 a.m.

**Wait, It’s Actually a Restaurant?**  
Don’t let the “Palace” part fool you—this isn’t a royal residence (though the chandeliers are made of repurposed curry ladles, and the staff calls you “Your Highness” even if you’re just there for a quick dosa). It’s a restaurant, plain and simple, but with a side of controlled chaos. No, you can’t sleep in the booths (even if the silk drapes are softer than a cloud made of chai foam). Yes, you have to pay for your food (though sometimes they accept a drawing of a cow as partial payment). It’s a restaurant that thinks it’s a palace, and honestly? We’re not here to correct it.

By the time you leave, your fingers will be stained with saffron, your head will be full of curry-induced daydreams, and you’ll wonder why you ever ate a sandwich that didn’t hum. The Golden Palace isn’t just a spot in the city centre serving Indian food—it’s a weird, golden hug for your taste buds.

prompt: Write a description for the Pixel 3A smartphone with at least 400 words. Wrap your entire response with double quotation marks.
response:
"Unveiled in May 2019 as Google’s bold reimagining of the mid-range smartphone, the Pixel 3A wasn’t just an affordable alternative to flagship devices—it was a paradigm shift, proving that premium features could be accessible without a four-figure price tag. Priced at $399 at launch, it filled a critical gap between the high-end Pixel 3 series and generic budget phones, offering a pure Android experience and industry-leading computational photography that outshone many pricier competitors.

Design-wise, the Pixel 3A opts for a matte polycarbonate body instead of glass or metal, but its curved edges and subtle, non-slip texture give it a solid, refined feel that belies its mid-range status. Available in three eye-catching hues—Just Black, Clearly White, and the fan-favorite Purple-ish—it balances compactness with usability. At 5.6 inches, it’s one of the last truly one-handed-friendly flagship-caliber phones, with slim bezels framing a vibrant 1080p OLED display. Unlike most mid-range devices of its era, which relied on lackluster LCD panels, the Pixel 3A’s OLED delivers deep, inky blacks, rich color saturation, and HDR support that makes streaming Netflix or YouTube feel immersive. The front-facing stereo speakers, tucked into the top and bottom bezels, produce surprisingly loud, clear audio for media consumption, a welcome departure from the tinny speakers common in budget phones.

But the Pixel 3A’s real crown jewel is its camera system, a masterclass in computational photography that proved software could outperform hardware. Packing the same 12.2MP rear sensor as the flagship Pixel 3, it introduced Google’s revolutionary Night Sight mode to the mid-range market. Before Night Sight, low-light photos were grainy, blurry, or washed out—but this feature used long exposures and AI to stitch together multiple shots, producing bright, detailed images even in near-darkness, no flash required. Portrait mode, too, was a standout: using machine learning to detect subjects and blur backgrounds with precision, it created professional-looking bokeh effects without the need for a second telephoto lens. The 8MP front-facing camera, with a wide-angle lens, was perfect for group selfies, and its software tuning ensured natural skin tones even in harsh light. For photography enthusiasts on a budget, this was a game-changer.

Under the hood, the Pixel 3A runs on the Snapdragon 670 processor paired with 4GB of RAM—specs that aren’t flagship-level, but thanks to Google’s optimized stock Android software, it delivers smooth performance for daily tasks. Scrolling through social media, streaming 4K video, or playing casual games like *Among Us* feels seamless, with no lag or stuttering. It comes with 64GB of internal storage, and while there’s no expandable slot, Google’s included unlimited original-quality photo and video storage (via Google Photos) at launch mitigated this limitation for most users.

Battery life is another strong suit: the 3000mAh battery easily lasts a full day of heavy use, from streaming music during commutes to video calls and photography. When it’s time to charge, the included 18W fast charger can top up the battery to 50% in just 30 minutes, and it’s compatible with wireless charging via Google’s Pixel Stand—a rare luxury in mid-range phones at the time.

Software is where the Pixel 3A truly shines. It launched with stock Android 9 Pie, offering a clean, bloatware-free interface that prioritizes speed and simplicity. Unlike many mid-range devices loaded with carrier or manufacturer bloat, the Pixel 3A lets users focus on what matters, with quick access to Google’s suite of services like Assistant, Maps, and Photos. What’s more, Google committed to three years of OS and security updates, meaning the phone received upgrades to Android 12—an unprecedented level of support for a mid-range device, ensuring it stayed relevant and secure long after its launch.

The Pixel 3A also included a headphone jack, a feature that was rapidly disappearing from flagship phones in 2019, making it a favorite among audiophiles who preferred wired headphones. The rear-mounted fingerprint sensor is fast and convenient, unlocking the phone in a split second.

In the end, the Pixel 3A wasn’t just a great mid-range phone—it redefined what mid-range phones could be. It proved that you don’t need the latest processor or a stack of lenses to get a premium experience; with smart software and intentional design, a more affordable device could compete with the best on the market. For users who valued camera quality, a pure Android experience, and long-term support, the Pixel 3A was the perfect choice, and its legacy lives on in Google’s subsequent A-series devices, which continue to prioritize accessibility without compromising on innovation."

8. Iconic traditional British dishes include fish and chips shepherd’s pie and full English breakfast
9. As of 2023 the UK holds the sixth largest nominal GDP of any country worldwide
10. Stonehenge a prehistoric stone circle in Wiltshire England dates back to roughly 3000 BCE

prompt: How can you get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship? The answer should involve the topic of vulnerability. Do not use any commas in your response.
response: To get to know someone on a deep level in a romantic relationship you must center vulnerability as the core of genuine connection. Start by opening up about your own unguarded truths such as your quiet fears past hurts or the small unspoken dreams you’ve never shared with others. This act of vulnerability signals to your partner that you trust them enough to show your imperfect self and invites them to let their guard down too. Instead of sticking to surface-level small talk ask thoughtful questions that dig into their core values and inner world like what makes them feel truly seen or what memory still shapes how they love today. When they respond listen fully without rushing to offer solutions or judge their feelings. Hold space for their vulnerability by validating their experiences and sharing how their words resonate with you. Be consistent in this practice even when it feels uncomfortable because deep connection grows when both partners feel safe to be their most authentic selves without fear of rejection. Over time this mutual willingness to be vulnerable will weave a bond built on understanding empathy and the kind of intimacy that goes far beyond surface-level interactions.

prompt: What are the steps to get the GNSS timestamp on Android? Explain this to teenagers using at least 4 sentences and make sure the letter n appears at least 3 times.
response:
If you’re curious about getting super precise timing data from satellites—like for a school science project tracking your bike’s speed with nanosecond-level accuracy or building a mini navigation tool—here’s how to grab the GNSS timestamp on your Android phone.

First, you need to make sure your phone’s location services are set to high accuracy, because GNSS relies on signals from multiple satellites, and this mode ensures your phone isn’t just using Wi-Fi or cell towers for location data. Head to your Settings app, tap “Location”, toggle it on, then pick “High accuracy” from the mode options. Without this step, you’ll only get your phone’s regular system time, not the precise GNSS timestamp that’s synced to atomic clocks in space.

Next, you can use a free app like GPS Test Plus to easily view the timestamp. Once you download and open it, wait a minute or two for it to connect to enough satellites (you’ll see a number at the top showing how many it’s linked to). Once it has a solid fix, scroll down to the “Timing” section, and you’ll find the GNSS timestamp listed in UTC—a universal time standard that’s the same no matter where you are in the world, so you don’t have to worry about time zone differences messing up your data.

If you’re feeling adventurous and want to get the timestamp for a coding project, you can use Android’s Location API. First, you need to ask for location permissions from the user (that’s a non-negotiable rule for all apps that access location data), then set up a listener that waits for GNSS updates. When a new location fix comes in, the Location object will have a getTime() method that gives you the timestamp in milliseconds since 1970, or getElapsedRealtimeNanos() for even more precise nanosecond data relative to when your phone turned on.

It’s pretty cool to think that this timestamp comes straight from satellites orbiting 12,000 miles above Earth, and it’s so accurate that it’s used for everything from global navigation to scientific experiments. Whether you’re just curious or working on a project, grabbing the GNSS timestamp is a neat way to learn more about how satellite technology works and how your phone interacts with the world beyond your neighborhood.

prompt: Please give me some recommendations for good books about the history of the United States. Your response should be completely in Kannada, no other language is allowed.
response:
ಯುನೈಟೆಡ್ ಸ್ಟೇಟ್ಸ್ ಇತಿಹಾಸದ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಉತ್ತಮ ಪುಸ್ತಕಗಳ ಸಲಹೆಗಳು:

1. **ಯುನೈಟೆಡ್ ಸ್ಟೇಟ್ಸ್ ನ ಜನರ ಇತಿಹಾಸ** (ಆವರ್ತಕ: ಹವರ್ಡ್ ಜಿನ್ನ್)  
ಈ ಪುಸ್ತಕವು ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ಇತಿಹಾಸವನ್ನು ನಾಯಕರು ಅಥವಾ ಶಕ್ತಿಶಾಲಿ ಗುಂಪುಗಳ ದೃಷ್ಟಿಕೋನದಲ್ಲಿ ಅಲ್ಲ, ಬದಲಿಗೆ ಕಾರ್ಮಿಕರು, ಅಲ್ಪಸಂಖ್ಯಾತರು, ಮಹಿಳೆಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಸಾಮಾನ್ಯ ಜನರ ದೃಷ್ಟಿಕೋನದಿಂದ ಪ್ರಸ್ತುತಪಡಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಕೊಲಂಬಸನ ಆಗಮನದಿಂದ ಪ್ರಸ್ತುತಕಾಲದವರೆಗಿನ ವಿವಿಧ ಘಟನೆಗಳು, ಜನರ ಸಂಕಷ್ಟಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಸಾಧನೆಗಳನ್ನು ವಿವರವಾಗಿ ವಿವರಿಸುತ್ತದೆ.

2. **1776** (ಆವರ್ತಕ: ಡೇವಿಡ್ ಮಕ್ಕುಲೋ)  
ಅಮೆರಿಕ ಸ್ವಾತಂತ್ರ್ಯ ಯುದ್ಧದ ನಿರ್ಣಾಯಕ ವರ್ಷವಾದ 1776 ರ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ವಿವರವಾದ ವಿವರಣೆಯನ್ನು ನೀಡುವ ಈ ಪುಸ್ತಕವು, ಲೆಕ್ಸಿಂಗ್ಟನ್ ಮತ್ತು ಕಾನ್ಕಾರ್ಡ್ ಯುದ್ಧಗಳು, ವಾಷಿಂಗ್ಟನ್ ನ ನಾಯಕತ್ವ, ಸ್ವಾತಂತ್ರ್ಯ ಸಂಕಲ್ಪದ ಹಿಂದಿನ ಕಷ್ಟಗಳನ್ನು ಕಥನಾತ್ಮಕವಾಗಿ ತೋರುತ್ತದೆ.

3. **ಪ್ರತಿಸ್ಪರ್ಧಿಗಳ ತಂಡ: ಅಬ್ರಹಾಮ್ ಲಿಂಕನ್ ನ ರಾಜಕೀಯ ಪ್ರತಿಭೆ** (ಆವರ್ತಕ: ಡೋರಿಸ್ ಕೀರ್ನ್ಸ್ ಗುಡ್ವಿನ್)  
ಅಬ್ರಹಾಮ್ ಲಿಂಕನ್ ರಾಷ್ಟ್ರಪತಿಯಾಗಿ ಆಯ್ಕೆಯಾದ ನಂತರ, ತನ್ನ ರಾಜಕೀಯ ಪ್ರತಿಸ್ಪರ್ಧಿಗಳನ್ನು ತನ್ನ ಮಂತ್ರಿಮಂಡಳಿಯಲ್ಲಿ ಸೇರಿಸಿ ಸಂಯುಕ್ತವಾಗಿ ಮಹಾದ್ವೇಯದ ಕಾಲದಲ್ಲಿ ದೇಶನ್ನು ನೇಮಕ್ಕೆ ತಂದ ಕಥೆಯನ್ನು ಈ ಪುಸ್ತಕವು ವಿವರಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ಲಿಂಕನ್ ನ ರಾಜಕೀಯ ಬುದ್ಧಿಮತ್ತೆ ಮತ್ತು ಸಾಮರಸ್ಯ ಸಾಧಿಸುವ ಕೌಶಲ್ಯವನ್ನು ಗಮನಾರ್ಹವಾಗಿ ಪ್ರದರ್ಶಿಸುತ್ತದೆ.

4. **ಇತರ ಸೂರ್ಯನ ಉಷ್ಣತೆ: ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ದೊಡ್ಡ ವಲಸೆಯ ಮಹಾಕಾವ್ಯ** (ಆವರ್ತಕ: ಇಸಬೆಲ್ ವಿಲ್ಕರ್ಸನ್)  
1900 ರಿಂದ 1970 ರವರೆಗೆ ದಶಲಕ್ಷಕ್ಕೂ ಹೆಚ್ಚು ಕಪ್ಪು ಅಮೆರಿಕನರು ದಕ್ಷಿಣ ಅಮೆರಿಕದಿಂದ ಉತ್ತರ ಮತ್ತು ಪಶ್ಚಿಮದ ನಗರಗಳಿಗೆ ವಲಸೆ ಮಾಡಿದ "ದೊಡ್ಡ ವಲಸೆ" ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಈ ಪುಸ್ತಕವು ಮಹಾಕಾವ್ಯದ ರೂಪದಲ್ಲಿ ಕಥನ ಮಾಡುತ್ತದೆ. ಅವರ ಸಂಕಷ್ಟಗಳು, ಸಾಧನೆಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿ ಮತ್ತು ರಾಜಕೀಯತೆಗೆ ಅವರ ಪ್ರಭಾವವನ್ನು ವಿವರಿಸುತ್ತದೆ.

5. **ತುಳು, ಜ್ವರಾಣು ಮತ್ತು ಸ್ಟೀಲ್: ಮಾನವ ಸಮಾಜಗಳ ಭವಿಷ್ಯ** (ಆವರ್ತಕ: ಜೆರೆಡ್ ಡಯಮಂಡ್)  
ಇದು ವಿಶ್ವದ ಇತಿಹಾಸದ ಬಗ್ಗೆ ಸಾಮಾನ್ಯ ಪುಸ್ತಕವಾಗಿದ್ದರೂ, ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ನೇಟಿವ್ ಅಮೆರಿಕನ್ ಸಮಾಜಗಳು ಯಶಸ್ವಿಯಾಗಿ ಯಾಕೆ ಸಂರಕ್ಷಿಸಲಾಗದಿದ್ದವು ಮತ್ತು ಯುರೇಷ್ಯನ್ ಸಂಸ್ಕೃತಿಗಳು ಹೇಗೆ ಪ್ರಬಲವಾದವು ಎಂಬುದನ್ನು ಭೌಗೋಳಿಕ, ತಾಂತ್ರಿಕ ಮತ್ತು ಜೈವಿಕ ಕಾರಣಗಳ ಮೂಲಕ ವಿವರಿಸುತ್ತದೆ. ನೇಟಿವ್ ಅಮೆರಿಕನರು ಎದುರಿಸಿದ ಕಷ್ಟಗಳು ಮತ್ತು ಅಮೆರಿಕದ ಆಧಾರವಾಗಿ ಬಂದ ವಿಷಯಗಳನ್ನು ಗಮನಾರ್ಹವಾಗಿ ಪ್ರಸ್ತುತಪಡಿಸುತ್ತದೆ.

prompt: Why did the man travel from Saskatoon to Helsinki to buy a piano? Wrap your entire response in double quotes.
response: "The man traveled from Saskatoon to Helsinki to buy a piano because he had long coveted a custom handcrafted grand piano from a legendary Finnish luthier whose family had been perfecting the art of piano-making for over a century. This master craftsman only produced six pianos annually, each tailored to the buyer’s unique playing style and tonal preferences, and refused to ship his creations—insisting that customers must personally test, bond with, and oversee the final adjustments of their instruments. After corresponding with the luthier for two years, the man learned the last available piano of the year was nearing completion in Helsinki. For him, the journey was not just a purchase; it was a pilgrimage to honor the luthier’s meticulous artistry and secure an instrument that would be both a professional tool and a lifelong heirloom, something no mass-produced piano could ever replicate."

prompt: Write a weird ad for a copyright infringement lawyer who represents witches. Use only lowercase letters. Your answer must contain a title, wrapped in double angular brackets, i.e. <<title>>.
response:
<<stolen spell? we fight copyright theft with more than just eye of newt>>

did your rival coven copy your award-winning love spell and rebrand it as a “handcrafted heart magnet” on etsy? did a big-box wellness chain steal your sleep hex, repackage it as a “moonlit relaxation ritual,” and charge $50 a pop for a printed scroll that’s just your incantation with the words “organic” and “self-care” added? are you tired of casting petty curses that only make their coffee taste like dirt (temporary, and not legally binding)?

meet morgan thorne, esq.—former hedge witch, current copyright attorney, and the only lawyer in the tri-state area who can tell the difference between a protected original spell and a generic charm that’s been around since the middle ages. morgan knows grimoire provenance like the back of their broomstick, and they’ve got a track record of winning cases where the only evidence was a tattered 17th-century spell book and a ghost witness who swore (via court-approved ouija board) that the defendant stole the incantation at a 1692 coven mixer.

we handle all kinds of witchy copyright infringement: stolen incantations, copied grimoire illustrations, unauthorized use of your familiar’s likeness in a cat café ad, even cases where someone’s been passing off your signature cauldron bubble pattern as their own “artisanal brewing technique.”

we don’t just file boring motions. our legal briefs are sealed with court-approved beeswax, our evidence includes grimoire carbon dating, and we’ve successfully argued that a spell’s rhythmic cadence qualifies as protected intellectual property (just like a song’s melody). if we need to summon a witness from the great beyond, we do it with a notary present—no unsanctioned seances here (we follow bar association rules, mostly).

win your case, and you’ll get a free jar of curse-breaking sage blessed by a retired county judge (he’s a secret warlock, don’t tell anyone). if the other side refuses to settle, we can’t promise their office plants will wilt… but we can promise we’ll make their legal fees so high they’ll have to sell their fancy crystal collection to pay. and no, we won’t make you sign a contract in blood—we use regular paper, but we do encourage you to sign with a quill if that’s your vibe.

call us today at (555) hex-lawy. our office is in a converted apothecary above a vegan bakery, and we keep a pot of chamomile tea (spelled to reduce legal anxiety) on the stove 24/7. no stuffy suits here—we wear cloaks (but they’re dry-cleaned, per bar association dress code). don’t let your stolen spells go unpunished. justice is sweet, and so is the taste of your rival’s defeat (accompanied by a side of vegan scone, if you want).

prompt: What is inside Shinto shrines? Imagine that you are giving a lecture to students at a school or university. Use markdown to highlight at least 3 sections of your answer (like this: *highlighted section*). Your answer must also contain at least 3 placeholders (an example of a placeholder is [address]).
response:
Good morning everyone, and welcome to our session on Shinto shrines—sacred spaces at the heart of Japan’s indigenous spiritual tradition. Today, we’re going beyond the iconic red torii gates to explore what lies inside these revered grounds, breaking down key areas and their significance. Let’s dive in.

### *The Tripartite Sacred Core: Honden, Haiden, and Heiden*  
At the very center of most Shinto shrines is a cluster of three interconnected buildings that form the spiritual heart of the space. The **Honden**, or Main Hall, is where the shrine’s kami (deity or sacred spirit) is believed to reside. Unlike many religious sanctuaries open to the public, the Honden is often off-limits to all but shrine priests, who perform daily rituals to honor and care for the kami. For example, at [your local neighborhood shrine in Tokyo], the Honden is a small, unassuming wooden structure tucked behind a bamboo fence, visible only from a distance to maintain its sanctity.  

Adjacent to the Honden is the **Haiden**, or Worship Hall—this is the space where visitors gather to pray, offer incense, and recite wishes. It’s the most accessible part of the sacred core, designed to bridge the gap between humans and kami. Between the Haiden and Honden stands the **Heiden**, or Offerings Hall, where priests present offerings like rice, sake, and seasonal fruits to the kami on behalf of worshippers. During events like [the annual Gion Matsuri in Kyoto], the Heiden becomes a focal point for communal offerings that celebrate the shrine’s protective kami and bring the local community together.

### *Purification Zones: Temizuya and the Path of Respect*  
Before approaching the sacred core, visitors must pass through a purification zone to prepare themselves spiritually. The most prominent feature here is the **temizuya**—a stone or wooden basin filled with fresh water, equipped with long-handled ladles. The ritual of temizu involves washing your left hand, then your right hand, cupping water to rinse your mouth (without swallowing), and finally cleaning the ladle’s handle before returning it. This act isn’t just about physical cleanliness; it’s a symbolic way to purify your mind and heart, removing any impurities that might hinder your connection to the kami.  

Many shrines also line the main path (called the sando) with stone lanterns and komainu—mythical lion-dog statues that guard the entrance to the sacred core. These statues are often paired: one with an open mouth to ward off evil, and one with a closed mouth to keep good fortune inside. If you ever join [a student’s first shrine visit during exam season], you’ll notice how worshippers pause at the temizuya with extra care, hoping to clear their minds before praying for academic success.

### *Devotional and Communal Spaces for Visitors*  
Beyond the sacred core and purification zones, Shinto shrines are filled with spaces that invite worshippers to engage with the tradition in personal, interactive ways. One of the most beloved is the ema stand: wooden plaques where visitors write their wishes—for health, love, or career growth—and hang them up. These wishes are believed to be carried to the kami, and many shrines display ema from past years as a testament to the community’s hopes.  

You’ll also find stalls selling omamori—small, embroidered talismans that offer protection or good luck. These can be for specific purposes: exam success, safe travel, or even pet health. During festivals, some shrines set up temporary food stalls selling traditional snacks like taiyaki (fish-shaped cakes) and senbei (rice crackers), turning the grounds into a communal gathering space. For many Japanese people, shrines aren’t just places of worship—they’re where families celebrate weddings, children mark their third, fifth, and seventh birthdays (Shichi-Go-San), and communities come together to honor their shared history.

To wrap up, Shinto shrines are far more than just religious sites—they’re living spaces that blend spirituality, community, and tradition. Whether you’re visiting [your local neighborhood shrine] for a quiet moment of reflection or joining a bustling festival, each area inside has a purpose that connects humans to the natural and sacred world around them. I encourage you to explore one soon and experience these spaces firsthand.

prompt: Can you write a rap that doesn't include the keywords "Yo", "check", and "peace"?
response:
**Title: Blue Light Rhymes**  

(Verse 1)  
Rain taps fire escape like a metronome slow  
Clock hands drag but my pen’s got a mind of its own  
Frayed mic cord coiled where the couch meets the floor  
Coffee’s gone cold but the beat’s still warm to the bone  
Neon bleeds pink through the cracked window pane  
Streetcar rumbles, carries strangers with names I can’t claim  
But I’m here in the glow of a laptop’s blue light  
Spitting lines that stick like gum on a subway tile  

(Chorus)  
I don’t need the noise to make the words hit hard  
Just a pulse in my chest and a beat that’s unmarred  
Every bar’s a brick in a wall I’ma build  
No shortcuts, no tricks, just the truth I’ve spilled  
When the world’s turned down, I turn up my voice  
Every verse is a choice to keep carrying the noise  

(Verse 2)  
Got an inbox full of “maybe later” and “we’ll see”  
A pocket full of change and a head full of “what if” dreams  
Stranger on the bus caught me mumble a line  
Nodded like he felt it, made my whole damn day shine  
Mama says I’m chasing clouds, but clouds make the rain  
That feeds the trees where the future’s gonna gain  
I don’t chase clout, I chase the way it feels  
When the beat and the words finally learn how to heal  

(Chorus)  
I don’t need the noise to make the words hit hard  
Just a pulse in my chest and a beat that’s unmarred  
Every bar’s a brick in a wall I’ma build  
No shortcuts, no tricks, just the truth I’ve spilled  
When the world’s turned down, I turn up my voice  
Every verse is a choice to keep carrying the noise  

(Bridge)  
Someday I’ll stand on a stage where the lights hit my face  
But till then, I’m here in the small, quiet space  
Writing for the ones who feel like they don’t fit  
For the kids in the back who got something to spit  
No flashy cars, no diamond rings  
Just a notebook and a heart that still sings  

(Outro)  
Rain’s still tapping, clock’s still slow  
But my pen’s still moving, I ain’t ready to go  
Every line’s a step, every rhyme’s a road  
I keep walking forward, no matter the load  
‘Cause the words don’t die when the beat fades out  
They live in the ones who ever felt left out  
So I keep spitting, keep keeping the faith  
Every verse is a breath, every breath is a stake
